question: The speed of sound in an ideal gas at a given temperature T is v. The rms speed of gas molecules at that temperature is <katex>$V_{rms}$</katex>. The ratio of the velocities v and <katex>$V_{rms}$</katex> for helium and oxygen gases are X and X' respectively. Then <katex>$\frac{X}{X^{\prime}}$</katex> is equal to
explanation: Speed of sound <katex>$v = \sqrt{\gamma RT/M}$</katex>. RMS speed <katex>$v_{rms} = \sqrt{3RT/M}$</katex>. Ratio <katex>$X = v/v_{rms} = \sqrt{\gamma/3}$</katex>. For He (monoatomic), <katex>$\gamma = 5/3$</katex>. <katex>$X = \sqrt{5/9}$</katex>. For O2 (diatomic), <katex>$\gamma = 7/5$</katex>. <katex>$X' = \sqrt{7/15}$</katex>. Ratio <katex>$X/X' = \sqrt{5/9} / \sqrt{7/15} = \sqrt{\frac{5}{9} \times \frac{15}{7}} = \sqrt{\frac{25}{21}} = \frac{5}{\sqrt{21}}$</katex>.
